title: Impact-Based Tornado Warning Communication Effectiveness in Moore, Oklahoma
abstract: Mixed-methods study examining public response to impact-based tornado warnings during the 2023 severe weather season. Combines survey data on warning reception and interpretation with behavioral observation data and emergency manager interviews to evaluate communication effectiveness.
purpose: To assess whether impact-based warning language improves public understanding and protective action taking compared to traditional warnings, informing National Weather Service communication strategies
creator: Dr. Rachel Thompson, University of Oklahoma
citation_recommendation: Thompson, R., Martinez, K., & Williams, A. (2023). Impact-Based Tornado Warning Communication Effectiveness in Moore, Oklahoma. University of Oklahoma. https://doi.org/10.5555/moore-tornado-warnings-2023
geographic_coverage_specific: Moore, Oklahoma and surrounding Cleveland County communities
spatial_resolution: Household level for surveys, ZIP code level for aggregated analysis
temporal_resolution: Event-based data collection during severe weather warnings plus post-season surveys
collection_methodology: Pre/post surveys via telephone and online platforms, real-time behavioral observation during warning events, semi-structured interviews with emergency managers and broadcast meteorologists
uncertainty_quantification: Survey confidence intervals at 95% level; response rates 28% pre-season, 41% post-event; qualitative data includes intercoder reliability statistics (Îº=0.84)
data_processing: Survey data weighted for demographic representativeness, qualitative data coded using framework analysis, warning message content analyzed using automated text analysis with manual verification
provenance: Data collected during 2023 severe weather season, interviews transcribed and coded fall 2023, final dataset compiled December 2023 with updated version including follow-up data January 2024
integration_with_other_data: Links to NWS warning database via event timestamps and geographic coordinates, compatible with Storm Events Database and local emergency response logs
software_dependencies: R 4.2+, survey package, qualitative analysis software (NVivo or similar)
access_restrictions: Interview transcripts require restricted access due to privacy; survey data publicly available with geographic identifiers removed
retention_policy: Maintained by University of Oklahoma Libraries with 15-year retention commitment, archived with NOAA National Centers for Environmental Information
